justification: The corporate tax report game is used as a measure of dishonesty, where participants can underreport company income to evade taxes, quantifying their level of dishonesty based on how much they deviate from the true income.

measured_by: adapted measure from Zickfeld et al. (2023)
justification: Participants are asked to rate their commitment to their group members on a scale from 1 to 7, before and after the tax report game, capturing changes in social commitment over the course of the experiment.

measured_by: items adapted from Motro et al. (2018)
justification: Three items measure participants' feelings of anger and guilt during the game using a 7-point scale, providing an index of moral emotions experienced during the task.

measured_by: one item scale based on Ścigała et al. (2025)
justification: Participants rate their current level of stress on a 5-point scale, offering a snapshot of their emotional state throughout the experiment.

measured_by: one-item scale adapted from Casal et al. (2016)
justification: Participants rate their general willingness to take risks on a scale from absolute risk aversion to absolute risk seeking, capturing individual differences in risk preferences.
The scale measures participant's tendency to be honest and humble with statements like 'I find it difficult to lie,' providing a personality index relevant to their ethical behavior.
